Award.AwardTitle: Low-Energy Charge Dynamics in Dirac Fermion Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Abstract:

The objective of this project is to better understand the exotic change dynamics in materials with a Dirac point close to the Fermi energy in their band structure. The classic example is graphene; however, topological insulators, which are bulk insulators, also have Dirac fermions in unique metallic chiral edge states. Despite numerous theoretical and experimental papers on this topic, several issues are still unresolved regarding the low-frequency conductivity, the importance of quasiparticle interactions and the role of impurities and defects in their electronic properties. Terahertz time-domain spectroscopy will be used to investigate the response of these materials in this previously unexplored frequency range. Along with important fundamental issues, these materials have the potential for new technological functionality from high-performance electronic devices to topological quantum computing. Understanding the charge dynamics at terahertz frequencies is a crucial component for pursuing some of these applications. Finally, this project will train two graduate students and postdoc in a quickly emerging area of nanoscience. UCR runs a Summer Bridge to Research program that supports summer research for undergraduates in STEM fields who are Hispanic and/or come from low-income families. Each summer, a student in this program will participate on this project.

Non-Technical Abstract:

As a result of their unique structure, Dirac fermion materials, such as graphene and topological insulators, have exotic electronic properties and display a wide range of fascinating phenomena, which is the reason they have attracted an enormous amount of interest. Fundamentally related to their properties is the response of the electrons to external electric fields. The objective of this project is to investigate this response at terahertz frequencies using time-domain spectroscopy. This type of an investigation in a previously unexplored frequency range is relevant to resolving several issues related to how the electrons interact with defects and with each other. These materials have the potential for new technological functionality from high-performance electronic devices to topological quantum computing. In addition to advancing our fundamental understanding, knowledge of the electron?s response at these frequencies is important for pursuing some of these new applications. Finally, this project will train two graduate students and postdoc in a quickly emerging area of nanoscience. UCR runs a Summer Bridge to Research program that supports summer research for undergraduates in STEM fields who are Hispanic and/or come from low-income families. Each summer, a student in this program will participate on this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The search for new materials with exotic properties that can be exploited for new functionality has been an important means of advancing technology. Recently, the focus is on materials where the charge carriers, referred to as Dirac fermions, have unusual characteristics due to the unique band-structure in the material when constrained to two dimensions. Two important examples are graphene, which is a single layer of carbon atoms on a hexagonal lattice, and the surface electronic states in a class of materials called topological insulators.  Studying the way these materials conduct electricity is important for understanding the underlying mechanisms and has a direct bearing on possible technological applications. The objective of this project was to investigate these materials at terahertz (THz) frequencies, which is just below the infrared, as a function of temperature. This research can provide insight into the low-energy excitations in these materials that are responsible for some of their interesting properties.

These measurements were conducted using a THz-Time-Domain Spectrometer (THz-TDS), which is capable of measuring the full transport response in a coherent fashion, eliminating the need for the usual assumptions in the analysis for traditional spectroscopy. Initially, the instrument utilized 10 cm diameter beams in a transmission configuration in order to precisely determine phase information for the signal. The system was also restricted to a narrow range around room temperature. In the first part of the project, the instrument was modified with polymethylpentene lens to reduce the beam diameter to approximately 9 mm for smaller samples. These changes also enhanced the instrument’s performance with an increase in the signal-to-noise from 1000:1 to 2500:1.

The optical response for several substrate materials was investigated, and GE-124 glass was selected because of its high transparency in the THz range while still providing a suitable growth platform for graphene. Samples with one-, two- and three-layer graphene were prepared by Graphene Laboratories, and data were collected on these samples at room temperature. While the properties of single-layer graphene are characterized by massless Dirac fermions, the Dirac cones are replaced by parabolic bands with an energy gap in bilayer graphene. This should lead to a significant difference in the transport properties measured at THz frequencies. These properties are represented by two parameters, the real and imaginary dielectric constants. Over this frequency range, the dielectric constant increases with the number of layers, and there is a distinct qualitative difference at the lowest frequencies between the single layer sample and the samples with more layers. 

Towards the end of the project., the spectrometer was being outfitted with a liquid-helium cryostat, which would extend the temperature range down to approximately 4 K. The significant challenges with this modification are the alignment of the THz beam through the confined space of the cryostat’s tailpiece and minimizing signal attenuation while maintaining adequate thermal isolation. Unfortunately, this phase of the project was not completed before the end of the grant.

For outreach, the PI participated in and contributed three $600 stipends to the Summer Academy at UCR. This was a one-week workshop, which was organized each year by the department, with the objective of providing professional development for physics teaches from Southern California. Many of these teachers come from schools with large populations of under-represented students. The talks given at the workshop cover topics on basic physics, current research and science pedagogy.
